node.text:
Still I rise... On June 19, 1865, US Brigadier General Gordon Granger and his troops landed at Galveston, Texas, confirming the news that the Civil War had ended and that enslaved African Americans were now free. #Juneteenth commemorates this important milestone. Although the ratification of the 13th Amendment in December 1865 ultimately abolished slavery, the struggle for equality continues today. Through the lens of our nation’s iconic places, the National Park Service has a responsibility to advance understanding of our nation’s unique and complex history. We invite you to watch “Twenty & Odd,” which builds on the innumerable contributions of African Americans to the foundation of the nation and explores the trauma, resilience, and beauty of the African American experience.

#FindYourPark #NationalParkService

node.text:
Set against 400 years of suffering, healing, and strength, with a backdrop of our nation’s most storied lands, the innumerable contributions of African Americans to the foundation of the United States are recognized in this short film.

#TwentyandOdd #NationalParkService #AfricanAmericanHistory #FindYourPark #StillIRise

node.title: Twenty & Odd: 400 Years of African American Experience

node.text:
“Am I a morning person? That would be an enthusiastic yes.” - Colin Robinson⁣⁣ ⁣⁣ ⁣
⁣
Energy a bit drained? Perhaps a beautiful sunrise is what you need? Acadia's landscape (great for daywalkers) features elements that have made Maine's coastline world famous, including rocky shores, crashing waves, tree-lined peaks, and the chance to witness a spectacular sunrise. (Spectacular sunrise not guaranteed; subject to weather, cloud cover, and your ability to get out of bed in time.) If you’re not a morning person, or feel like hanging out in the shadows, perhaps a sunset is more to your taste? ⁣
⁣
Have you ever gotten up early to catch the sunrise in a national park? Maybe you stuck around for a sunset? ⁣
⁣
Video: Time-lapse of sunrise along Ocean Drive. NPS⁣ @acadianps 
⁣
#sunrise #timelapse #acadianationalpark #maine #morningperson

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service in Katmai National Park & Preserve. May be an image of nature and body of water.

node.text:
That awkward moment when you realize the bear is not waving at you, but the bear behind you….⁣
⁣
D’oh! Stay alert. Katmai’s bears are mostly diurnal (active during the day) but are also active at night and can be found in all of Katmai’s habitats. Never assume you are in a “bear free” area. Be on the lookout for signs of bears and be especially wary in areas where bears may have trouble detecting you. Sometimes, you might see a bear before it is aware of you. In these situations, back away quietly the same way you came and give the bear space.⁣
⁣
The best defense is knowledge, preparation, and prevention. Arm yourself with a knowledge of bear biology, ecology, and behavior. Prepare yourself mentally for bear encounters before you visit Katmai or any park with bears. Learn more tips by visiting the park’s website at nps.gov/katm ⁣
⁣
Image: In the far distance, a bear stands with a paw raised. Be polite and wave back.NPS\R Taylor ⁣
⁣
#awkward #wave #bear #Alaska #katmainationalpark

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service in National Mall and Memorial Parks. May be an image of one or more people, monument, outdoors and text.

node.text:
On August 28, 1963, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. delivered his "I Have a Dream" speech from the steps of the Lincoln Memorial. King's speech was the grand finale of the "March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom." His words have endured as one of the signature moments of the civil rights movement.  The location of the podium is marked on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial.
⁣
Image:  The words “I Have a Dream" etched on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial, part of @nationalmallnps.
⁣
#nationalparkservice #lincolnmemorial #mlkjr #ihaveadream #washingtondc

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service in Big Bend National Park. May be an image of crustacean and outdoors.

node.text:
Mitey fine…⁣
⁣
Trombidiidae, also known as red velvet mites are small arachnids found in plant litter and are known for their bright red color. (Not their love of cake.) Also known as Rain Bugs, red velvet mites emerge from the ground after heavy summer rains. ⁣
⁣
Most of the year they hide underground in silk-lined caverns but will emerge once a year to conduct an unusual courtship. Look them up and learn about their “love garden,”intricate silken trail, and mating dance. You mite find it interesting. ⁣
⁣
It's hard to tell from this picture, but they are quite large - for a mite. They can grow up to 5 mm long, about the size of a pencil eraser. Their short hairs give it a soft, velvety appearance. Adult red velvet mites eat insect eggs and prey on very small invertebrates such as ants and other plant-eating insects. Few, if any, predators prey on these mites. This might be due to the fact that they taste really bad. Most importantly, they are absolutely harmless to human beings.⁣
⁣
Image: Close up of mite on a rock at @bigbendnps. NPS/J. Moore⁣
⁣
#bigbend #bigbendnationalpark #redvelvetmite #tinyanimals #texas #mite

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service in Grand Teton National Park. May be an image of dog.

node.text:
Hold on everyone, my internet connection is a bit ruff…⁣
⁣
And we’re back. It’s been a busy summer, so it’s all paws on deck. (Desk?) Bark Ranger Grizz has been helping out around @grandtetonnps, especially on #NationalDogDay! ⁣
⁣
For many, pets are an important member of our families. If you are planning to bring a furry family member on your trip to a park, make sure you are prepared to follow the B.A.R.K. Ranger code. The code helps protect you, your pet, and the park. If the activities you have planned for your visit do not allow for pets or are unsafe, consider leaving them at home. ⁣
⁣
B.A.R.K. stands for:⁣
⁣
🦮 Bag your pet’s waste⁣
⁣
🦮 Always leash your pet⁣
⁣
🦮 Respect wildlife⁣
⁣
🦮 Know where you can go⁣
⁣
Image: Dog wearing a Ranger hat (quite fetching), while sitting at desk with a computer. A cat silently judges in the background. ⁣
⁣
#dogdays #grandtetonnationalpark #barkranger #nationalparkservice #officelife

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service in Pullman National Monument, National Park Service. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text:
Designated in 2015, Pullman National Monument is the first National Park Service unit in Chicago. Preserving the story of one of the first planned industrial communities in the United States, the park includes many historic buildings located in what is now the Pullman neighborhood of Chicago. ⁣ Also within the district is the A. Philip Randolph Pullman Porter Museum, named for the prominent labor and civil rights leader A. Philip Randolph, which recognizes and explores African American labor history.
⁣
On September 4-5, the public will be welcome to take special tours of the new Pullman National Monument Visitor Center and the historic Hotel Florence. Free tickets for these tours will be available day-of on a first-come, first-served basis at the Information Tent, which will be at the southeast corner of 111th Street and Cottage Grove Avenue. There will be no admittance to these sites on grand opening weekend without a ticket. Ticketing will start at 9:00 am each day and last until all tickets are distributed. Each ticket will have a reserved entry time. Visitors will be required to wear a face covering for the tours. Stay up to date on Grand Opening weekend activities and coronavirus guidance at go.nps.gov/pullmangrandopening ⁣
 ⁣
Image: Pullman National Monument’s new Visitor Center, an ideal first stop for visitors to the Monument, will be located in the Historic Administration Clock Tower Building, 11001 S. Cottage Grove Ave. NPS /Daniel Pels⁣
⁣
#chicago #pullman #nationalparkservice #labordayweekend #illinois #architecture #pullmannationalmonument

location.name: Pullman National Monument, National Park Service

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service in Wind Cave National Park. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
It’s our buff-day! 🦬⁣
⁣
Sorry, birthday! We’re going to party like it's our birthday. Hey, like starlings on a bison, we’re just winging it. ⁣
⁣
This bison doesn’t look too excited, but it’s only Wednesday. Seeing a bison in person can be an amazing experience. But do be careful. They are big, can run pretty fast, and don’t mind taking you down a few pegs. ⁣
⁣
What may attract a bison to you? Bison are attracted to areas with protein-rich vegetation, tall grasses, and fear. Just kidding, it’s mainly the greens. Perhaps, you should avoid standing in their grass buffet. ⁣
⁣
Sometimes, you may be extremely careful, meticulously follow all regulations and bison safety tips, yet still come across a bison. If they don’t move, it's you who should back away. No shame. You know your abilities. Walk away so you can walk away from another animal on another day. ⁣
⁣
If a bison does start to head your way, secure the pants, back away slowly and don’t run or make sudden movements. ⁣
⁣
Now there are some clear signs that a bison is agitated and might ruin your day. Watch for and retreat when you notice agitation. An ‘agitated bison’ (Good name for a band. We called it first) is not something you want to mess with. Signs of agitation include: snorting, shaking or tossing of its head, pawing the ground, raising its tail, and bluff charges. (Similar to us getting out of bed and ready for work each morning.) ⁣
⁣
In conclusion, happy buff-day. Let’s make good choices and have safe park experiences. ⁣
⁣
Image: A bison with several starlings (they are clearly here for the appetizers) perched on its back at @windcavenps in South Dakota. NPS/ Kim Acker⁣
⁣
#bison #buffalo #windcave #nps105 #birthday #nationalparkservice

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service on August 25, 2021. May be a cartoon of text that says 'National Park Service'.

node.text:
On August 25, 1916, the National Park Service was officially created. For 105 years, the National Park Service has been entrusted with the care of our national parks. With the help of volunteers, partners, and you, we safeguard these special places and share their stories with millions of visitors every year. ⁣
⁣
Today, the National Park Service comprises 423 park sites covering more than 84 million acres in 50 states, the District of Columbia, American Samoa, Guam, Puerto Rico, Saipan, and the Virgin Islands. These parks preserve our nation’s pristine scenery, natural wonders, cultural and historical monuments, places of deep meaning, and moments of great change.⁣⁣
⁣
Graphic: Includes text reading "National Public Lands Day. National Park Service". Illustration is a silhouette of a park ranger filled with a collage of park-related images of cultural sites, wildlife, fossils, and more.⁣ NPS/Turner
⁣
#NPSBirthday #nps105 #findyourpark #nationalparkservice

node.text:
Free face hugs?⁣
⁣
Seems like a fungi? Earthstar mushrooms (Geastrum triplex) are unique fungi that can be found in woody areas along Cape Cod. The fruiting "bodies" of earthstars are hygroscopic, which means that they absorb moisture from the air. In dry weather the petals will curl up around the body of the mushroom to protect it. In wet weather, the petals moisten and uncurl, even curling backwards and lifting the body of the mushroom in the air. Earthstars reproduce by pushing spores out from a pore at the top of the sac to be distributed by the wind. ⁣
⁣
Video: Time lapse of mushroom at @capecodnps with petals unfurling as water is dripped onto it. NPS ⁣
⁣
#mushroom #nature #timelapse ⁣
#FindYourPark #EncuentraTuParque #fungi

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service on August 23, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text:
The Castillo de San Marcos is unique in North American architecture. As the only extant 17th century military construction in the country and the oldest masonry fortress in the United States it is a prime example of the "bastion system" of fortification, named for the projecting diamond or angle shaped formations added onto the fort walls.⁣
⁣
It is also unique for the material used in its construction. The Castillo is one of only two fortifications in the world built out of a semi-rare form of limestone called coquina (The other is Fort Matanzas National Monument 14 miles south) Given its light and porous nature, coquina would seem to be a poor choice of building material for a fort.  However, coquina's porosity turned out to have an unexpected benefit. Because of its conglomerate mixture coquina contains millions of microscopic air pockets making it compressible. A cannon ball fired at more solid material, such as granite or brick would shatter the wall into flying shards, but cannon balls fired at the walls of the Castillo burrowed their way into the rock and stuck there. So the thick coquina walls absorbed or deflected projectiles rather than yielding to them, providing a surprisingly long-lived fortress. ⁣
⁣
Image 1: Aerial view of the Castillo de San Marcos showing four bastions. @castillonps ⁣
⁣
Image 2: View of fort walls made with coquina in St. Augustine, Florida. ⁣
⁣
#fort #florida #stagustine #fortification #castillodesanmarcos ⁣

location.name: Castillo de San Marcos National Monument

node.text:
Sea otters have flaps of loose skin under each forearm that they use like a pocket. That’s it. That’s the post. Just kidding. Let’s dive in. ⁣
⁣
What are these pockets full of? Well, it’s not sunshine. When swimming, the pockets are used to carry as much food as possible back to the surface. (Think buffet. You’ve already got a plate piled high of seafood and then you see hot rolls…oh, is that a pie? Alright! Let’s do this.)⁣
⁣
Otters also use their pockets to stash rocks. Rocks are used to crack open clams, crabs and other shellfish on their tummies. (Tummies is the preferred lingo.) They may also use rocks to hammer abalone shells, as quickly as 45 times in just 15 seconds (hammer time!), until the abalone loosen their tight grip on the seafloor. ⁣
⁣
Have rock, will travel. Many otters have a favorite rock that they store in their pocket, carrying it wherever they go. Some may even name their rocks. All hail “Sir Cracks A Lot,” bringer of otter destruction! Something like that. Research is pending. ⁣
⁣
Image: An otter floats on its back while eating fresh mussels. NPS/Anne Langan @kenaifjordsnps ⁣
⁣
#otterlife #ottersofinstagram #seaotters #alaska #finedining #seafood #rockstyle ⁣

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service in Mount Rainier National Park. May be an image of tree and nature.

node.text:
“Always follow your heart unless your heart is bad with directions.” – Spongebob ⁣
⁣
There’s nothing wrong with following your heart, but balance it with using your head…and maybe a map. Picking the right trail for you and your group is also important. Are you ready, kids?⁣
⁣
Three hours later…⁣
⁣
Your heart is saying “I could hike up these boulders for hours!” (You know, the ones pioneers used to ride for miles?) However, your feet are saying, “you wore flip flops…why are you like this?” Recognize your abilities and the abilities of your group. Pick a trail that everyone is prepared for and can successfully complete and enjoy safely. Check a park’s website or ask a ranger for details on the difficulty level of trails.⁣
⁣
Image: Sunlight streams through tree canopy above a large fallen log on the trail to Green Lake at Mount Rainier National Park, Washington. ⁣
⁣
#traillife #mountrainiernationalpark #washingtonstate #hikingadventures #trailblazer #askdirections
